patterns.pattern: First-time contributors with XS/S size labels receive significant merge probability boost despite lacking prior history, with XS/S labels correlating to 26-28% merge rates and providing 2-4% uplift over baseline
High-priority categories (agents, gateway, commands) provide 15-25% baseline merge rate uplift independent of author credentials, partially compensating for weak author signals
Fix-type changes receive 10-20% merge probability boost over feature additions, with narrow scope fixes receiving additional 5-10% boost

Authors with 0% historical merge rate across 3+ prior PRs face deterministic rejection risk unless compensated by explicit credibility labels (maintainer, trusted-contributor, experienced-contributor) or high-priority category with narrow scope

Missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, test coverage, CI status) consistently imposes 7-8% confidence penalty, but penalty is substantially mitigated by explicit size labels or established author history
Experienced-contributor or trusted-contributor labels provide 5-15% credibility boost that can offset poor historical merge performance when paired with high-priority categories
Multi-component scope (touching multiple channels/areas) reduces merge likelihood by 25-30% for weak authors but has minimal penalty for established contributors with strong merge history
Authors with established PR volume (50+ prior PRs) demonstrate consistent contribution patterns and retain moderate merge likelihood even when merge rate is below 24% baseline

Critical-path infrastructure changes (cron, session management, authentication) require explicit credibility signals (maintainer label or established merge history) from first-time contributors, and fix classification alone does not compensate
Authors with 100% merge rate history (even single prior PR) signal strong credibility and exceed 50% merge likelihood when paired with focused scope and high-priority categories

L and XL size labels (large scope) are strong rejection signals correlating with 15-20% merge rates, overriding compensatory signals and creating deterministic rejection risk for first-time contributors
Documentation-only PRs from first-time contributors have depressed baseline (20-30% merge rate), further reduced by 10-15% when touching multiple component areas

Authors demonstrating persistence through multiple revision attempts (v2, v3 submissions) on same issue show commitment signal that partially compensates for 0% merge history in high-priority categories
Narrow component scope (single channel, single area) provides 5-10% merge boost for first-time contributors, with maximum benefit when paired with fix-type classification
Issue references provide specificity boost (particularly when addressing documented bugs) that can elevate merge probability by 5-10%, indicating targeted, intentional contributions
